snippet.textDisplay:
In Swedish (and Danish, Norwegian, Icelandic, Esperanto, Polish, Russian) the lesbian romance example would actually be unambiguous, as it has reflexive possessive pronouns. I.e. the possessive pronoun changes depending on whether it refers to the subject of the sentence or someone else.


'Anna sat down next to Cathy and started playing with her skirt.'

'her skirt' would translate to either 'sin kjol' or 'hennes kjol' depending on whether the skirt is Anna's or Cathy's.
snippet.textOriginal:
In Swedish (and Danish, Norwegian, Icelandic, Esperanto, Polish, Russian) the lesbian romance example would actually be unambiguous, as it has reflexive possessive pronouns. I.e. the possessive pronoun changes depending on whether it refers to the subject of the sentence or someone else.


'Anna sat down next to Cathy and started playing with her skirt.'

'her skirt' would translate to either 'sin kjol' or 'hennes kjol' depending on whether the skirt is Anna's or Cathy's.

snippet.textDisplay:
Using AIDungeon to evaluate ML state of the art language models is a bit like letting a backgammon model run on Starcraft 2 tasks: it doesn't really make sense. You're asking a very narrow AI to guess outputs based on it having trained on choose-your-adventure narratives. Really, machines aren't only really kind of amazing already in extracting (cross-language) features from a set of specific text corpora, you also have features already helping in resolving ambiguity; in fact, many grammar helper extensions and addons aid in getting rid of garden path sentences and in pointing out some of the more difficult idiosyncrasies of each language.


While this doesn't exactly mean understanding in a broader, more philosophical sense (a whole different can of worms), we still have been setting plenty of precedents for ML being capable of much more than people ever expected, in the very foreseeable future. Be it sentiment or just automatic voice transcription - hell, even voice assistance has gotten so much better over the last few years alone and is seeing noticeable improvements all the time.


The wave hasn't quite arrived yet, so skepticism is of course understandable, but the pieces are aligning neatly and as fast as ever - and everything around us is going to shift shape in such a drastic manner, it's going to be really fun to watch.
snippet.textOriginal:
Using AIDungeon to evaluate ML state of the art language models is a bit like letting a backgammon model run on Starcraft 2 tasks: it doesn't really make sense. You're asking a very narrow AI to guess outputs based on it having trained on choose-your-adventure narratives. Really, machines aren't only really kind of amazing already in extracting (cross-language) features from a set of specific text corpora, you also have features already helping in resolving ambiguity; in fact, many grammar helper extensions and addons aid in getting rid of garden path sentences and in pointing out some of the more difficult idiosyncrasies of each language.


While this doesn't exactly mean understanding in a broader, more philosophical sense (a whole different can of worms), we still have been setting plenty of precedents for ML being capable of much more than people ever expected, in the very foreseeable future. Be it sentiment or just automatic voice transcription - hell, even voice assistance has gotten so much better over the last few years alone and is seeing noticeable improvements all the time. 


The wave hasn't quite arrived yet, so skepticism is of course understandable, but the pieces are aligning neatly and as fast as ever - and everything around us is going to shift shape in such a drastic manner, it's going to be really fun to watch.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you've got AI that can already understand English syntax, then that already seems impressive to me. Wouldn't it be a relatively easy thing to teach end-users to use short sentences and not use ambiguous words like "it", compared to teaching them obscure syntax like cout statements and for loops?

From the way you describe it, it sounds like teaching machines to understand ambiguous references is impossible until they already reach sentience and can experience the world like we do. So I would put the goal of getting a computer to understand "it" on the backburner for now.
snippet.textOriginal:
If you've got AI that can already understand English syntax, then that already seems impressive to me.  Wouldn't it be a relatively easy thing to teach end-users to use short sentences and not use ambiguous words like "it", compared to teaching them obscure syntax like cout statements and for loops?  

From the way you describe it, it sounds like teaching machines to understand ambiguous references is impossible until they already reach sentience and can experience the world like we do.  So I would put the goal of getting a computer to understand "it" on the backburner for now.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think this is good to know when you're teaching something to someone. We sometimes make the assumption that people know something we do and just rabble on. It is then hard for the person you're instructing to carry on with the rest of the information as they're stuck trying to interpret the information correctly.
It's also interesting how we can assemble bits of information in those situations to figure out the context and function of the words we are unfamiliar with. I wonder how much of that is looked into with machine learning.
snippet.textOriginal:

It is then hard for the person you're instructing to carry on with the rest of the information as they're stuck trying to interpret the information correctly.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have often wondered why no one has taken the approach of teaching humans to give intelligible commands rather than trying to make a machine that can understand every possible phrasing. Obviously long term the latter is the goal, but in the meantime the current approach to NLP makes it so inconsistent that it's usually little more than a novelty.

Voice commands are really only useful if they are deterministic and consistent a vast majority of the time, because if there's even a small chance that I'll have to repeat myself or cancel an incorrect action, it becomes much less troublesome to just do it with traditional controls.

Given that humans have so much experience and context, doesn't it make sense to take advantage of that ability when designing our systems?
snippet.textOriginal:
I have often wondered why no one has taken the approach of teaching humans to give intelligible commands rather than trying to make a machine that can understand every possible phrasing. Obviously long term the latter is the goal, but in the meantime the current approach to NLP makes it so inconsistent that it's usually little more than a novelty. 

Voice commands are really only useful if they are deterministic and consistent a vast majority of the time, because if there's even a small chance that I'll have to repeat myself or cancel an incorrect action, it becomes much less troublesome to just do it with traditional controls.

Given that humans have so much experience and context, doesn't it make sense to take advantage of that ability when designing our systems?

snippet.textDisplay: I have seen many times where, what I believe are called "indirect pronouns", have caused confusion and unnecessary expense. Using "it" or "that", "those", etc., instead of the proper names of things may be easier, but, a limited vocabulary is Nothing to be proud of. Life is not so short that communication be damned.

snippet.textDisplay:
One of the most inexplicably odd gesticulations that somehow manages to be both awkwardly intrusive, yet coweringly defensive at the same time.

It's as if you're attempting to preemptively push your audience away in a palmed jabbing motion, yet at the same time spastically shielding yourself from an imaginary attack.

No need to be so offensively defensive with your gesticulating.

No one's attacking you. Really. Not.

I am... not...

No, I'm not!

What? What kind of game is this? What are you playing at, Hermance? [L']Attaque(!)

snippet.textDisplay:
I always find it super annoying when I ask the Google assistant what the weather is going to be like tomorrow in German.
"Tomorrow" means "morgen". The problem is that "Morgen", which of course is pronounced the same way, means "morning", and of course Google tells me the weather for the next morning and not the whole day.
Another great example for German being weird is the word "umfahren". It has two completely opposite meanings: Drive around something or running over something.
snippet.textOriginal:
I always find it super annoying when I ask the Google assistant what the weather is going to be like tomorrow in German. 
"Tomorrow" means "morgen". The problem is that "Morgen", which of course is pronounced the same way, means "morning", and of course Google tells me the weather for the next morning and not the whole day.
Another great example for German being weird is the word "umfahren". It has two completely opposite meanings: Drive around something or running over something.

snippet.textDisplay: "Artificial language processing remains ten years away - just as it has for the last few decades." -- if you're trying to solve something, and you're essentially where you were before, it's likely that the solution is something you haven't thought of yet. Sure, pushing a "workable" solution to its limits usually means the results you get end up getting will be "good enough" - but while a VHS, after a lot of work, was eventually made "good enough" to store quality video, it doesn't hold a candle to DVDs (which themselves are technologically obsolete at this point). Here's hoping. :-)
snippet.textOriginal: "Artificial language processing remains ten years away - just as it has for the last few decades." -- if you're trying to solve something, and you're essentially where you were before, it's likely that the solution is something you haven't thought of yet. Sure, pushing a "workable" solution to its limits usually means the results you get end up getting will be "good enough" - but while a VHS, after a lot of work, was eventually made "good enough" to store quality video, it doesn't hold a candle to DVDs (which themselves are technologically obsolete at this point). snippet.textDisplay:
Machine learning engineer here, i have worked a bit with GPT-2 and other NLP models, and the reason they can't handle these cases is that they are not trained for that specific purpose. They are trained to know general language structures and to write sentences that are grammatically correct and sort of connected to some context.
Think of it like this, they have been trained to write down believable equations like "3x + 2y = 7", but they cant solve those equations because it is a fundamentally different task than writing them. And they haven't been trained for that.
I believe these models could probably handle some Winograd tests if they were trained for that purpose, but sadly it wouldn't prove that they had a greater understanding of the world, just that they had learned a bit more grammar.
snippet.textOriginal:
Machine learning engineer here, i have worked a bit with GPT-2 and other NLP models, and the reason they can't handle these cases is that they are not trained for that specific purpose. They are trained to know general language structures and to write sentences that are grammatically correct and sort of connected to some context. 
Think of it like this, they have been trained to write down believable equations like "3x + 2y = 7", but they cant solve those equations because it is a fundamentally different task than writing them. And they haven't been trained for that. 
I believe these models could probably handle some Winograd tests if they were trained for that purpose, but sadly it wouldn't prove that they had a greater understanding of the world, just that they had learned a bit more grammar.

snippet.textDisplay:
Doesn't matter which way you look at it, this group of words in the video is trying to be comprehensible, however, it doesn't say anything, it's just a bunch of words.


Grammatically, it is also incorrect "The trophy would not fit in the brown suitcase because it was too big" = Adverb Verb Pronoun Adverb Verb Pronoun Adverb Adjective Pronoun Adverb Verb Adverb Dangling Participle Verb.

snippet.textDisplay: Without watching the video past the reading of the suitcase sentence, I say "it" refers to "trophy" for two reasons. Obviously, the suitcase being too big makes no sense, but also, "trophy" is the subject, so I'd guess it's more likely that it is the antecedent anyway.
snippet.textOriginal: Without watching the video past the reading of the suitcase sentence, I say "it" refers to "trophy" for two reasons.  Obviously, the *suitcase* being too big makes no sense, but also, "trophy" is the subject, so I'd guess it's more likely that it is the antecedent anyway.

snippet.textDisplay: it would take an incredible amount of work but if you were to program a language program to understand words by tagging the concepts and concept interactions dealt with by the words you could probably get around that problem, if the computer knows that a suitcase is something that holds things inside of it and it knows that the verb "fits" references to the concept of things inside other things, then there is a line of logic for code to follow between those two concepts to be able to figure it out, that would however require you to think about every individual word to deduce a purely logical definition for the word and make sure that definition fits with the thousands of other definitions you'll be writing, prob start with nouns and verbs, a program may be able to get by with those alone but adjectives will end up being very important to this as they are effectively concepts that modify concepts, if your code can understand that I would argue it's well on the way to true intelligence
